bioghist.p: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia was founded in 1812 "for the encouragement and cultivation of the sciences, and the advancement of useful learning." Its collections, acquired through expeditions, gifts, purchases, and exchanges, contain over 17,000,000 specimens. The Department of Vertebrate Zoology is a section within the Center for Systematic Biology and Evolution. Included among the specimens maintained by the department is the Herpetology Collection, which is one of the most biologically diverse collections of its kind, with more than 500 named forms and many primary types.

scopecontent.p: This is a small collection of records related to snake, amphibian, and reptile specimens in the Vertebrate Biology Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences, 1936-1972. Included are: lists of specimens, some with dates, locations, and collectors; and a field catalog of amphibians and reptiles collected by Thomas Uzzell, in 1972 and 1973, in Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras. The collection also includes two completed internal questionnaires for curators at the Academy dating from 1968.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
